bibl.title: Letter from Jedediah Tingle to Mabel H. Lazear, June 4, 1927

div1.p: "Tingle" decries the lack of recognition of Lazear's heroism and sends some money to Mabel Lazear. The stationery is imprinted with the story of Tingle, a pseudonym used by philanthropists who wish to remain anonymous.

div1.head: Letter from Jedediah Tingle to Mabel H. Lazear, June 4, 1927
div1.p:
J.T+1750-1820
June 4, 1927. Mrs. Jesse Lazear,
Care of Adjutant General,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Mrs. Lazear:

How emotional, mercurial, thoughtless
is mankind. On Admiral Dewey's arrival from his
Manilla victory, it drove itself half mad with
enthusiasm, showering him with honors and gifts, and
a week later buried him in vindictive anathema for
giving to his wife one of the public offerings, a home,
like the gallant gentleman he always was.

Today the world is hysteria driven
over the truly marvelous sporting achievment of
Charlie Lindbergh, but I fear me much that tomorrow
or next day the wind of public favor will blow
chill from another quarter due to some trivial error
the young man may make - perhaps unconsciously.

I think the most or one of the most
pathetic evidences of injustice in the distribution
of honors for heroism at the hands of a democracy
was in the case of your husband who laid down his
life so willingly on the battlefield of science for
life and health and through whose sacrifice thousands
are in the world today and countries have been
peopled and prospered that were heretofore a pest hole.
No honor could have wiped out his loss but at least
the nation might have indicated a recognition of its
debt by crowning his loved ones with public
favor and surrounding them with some of the
luxuries within its vast power. However, dear Mrs. Lazear,
there are tenacious memories even in a democracy and a
thousand years hence Jesse will be better known and
more widely honored than today. As a token of my own
belated recognition of the lowly and voiceless, I am
enclosing my check for twenty dollars, drawn out perhaps
not so much by your needs and Jesse's desserts as by
a feeling of sadness that his grave is not heaped with
flowers and watered with tears, and that you are not
one of the publicly honored of the nation.

Yours sincerely,
Jedediah Tingle
In acknowledging, address in care of
The American Trust Company
209 Montague Street
Brooklyn, N.Y.

Reprint from the Bowling Green Column of the New
York Evening Post.

Occasionally, in recent years, various people have
been startled to receive a letter, most charmingly
phrased, expressing gratitude for something they have
done or painted or written or said, and signed Jedediah
Tingle. These people have justly suspected that
Jedediah Tingle is a pseudonym, but they have found
that the check was perfectly valid and cashable or the
book worth reading.

Now one of the most pleasing adventures we have
had lately was a call from Mr. Tingle himself. He
did not come, we must explain, to exert his benevo-
lence upon ourself, but to consult us about a certain
phase of his recreation of secretly rewarding, in a
modest way, those whose works appealed to him.
He did not tell us his real name, and we have no
desire to know who he is, other than that he is a
thoughtful business man who has found great delight
in these mysterious gestures of helpfulness. To
identify him would not only necessarily put an end
to his cheerful avocation, but would also deprive the
situation of its unique charm.

The secret circle of those who have received these
letters from Jedediah Tingle is a curiously assorted
one. We have had some of the letters shown us, in
the past, by those who have received them. These
letters have gone to Cabinet Ministers and to obscure,
struggling poets, to great writers and to unknown
heroes. But the point is this--while Mr. Tingle tells
us he has greatly enjoyed the occasional acknowledg-
ments that have come to him by being addressed to
the banks on which his checks are drawn, certain
individuals and newspapers have made determined
attempts to unmask his innocent secret. We would
like to ask all Managing Editors and others to be
good sports and not spoil this admirable innocent
generosity by trying to discover its source.

The undersigned feels mildly resentful at being
called a “pseudonym.” He harbors a strong suspicion
that he is the living incarnation of his own great
grandfather whose name he has taken and who in
turn came from generations of Abou Ben Adhems.

In 1820 they placed his bones in a country grave-
yard in the Middle West, now an abandoned tangle
of grasses, briars and broken
trees, but that event was
probably merely an episode
in an eternal mission, which
is to bring smiles and tender
thoughts to the great in heart
--in high and low places. To
comfort and cheer those who
do exceptional things, or
suffer.
